ingestedContentSummary.description: Background Post-treatment evaluation of patients with rectal cancer (RC) using magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) burdens medical resources, necessitating an expl...
ingestedContentSummary.fullText: Post-treatment evaluation of patients with rectal cancer (RC) using magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) burdens medical resources, necessitating an exploration of abbreviated protocols This retrospective study included RC patients who underwent non-contrast rectal MRI and standard liver MRI, as well as abdominal contrast-enhanced computed tomography (CECT) for post-treatment evaluation. A-MRI comprised diffusion-weighted imaging (DWI) and T2-weighted imaging of the upper abdomen and the pelvic cavity. Three radiologists independently reviewed A-MRI, CECT, and standard liver MRI in the detection of viable disease. The diagnostic performances were compared using a reference standard considering all available information, including pathology, FDG-PET, endoscopic results, and clinical follow-up. We included 78 patients (50 men, 28 women; mean age=60.9 ± 10.2 years) and observed viable disease in 34 (43.6%). On a per-patient-basis analysis, A-MRI showed significantly higher sensitivity (95% vs. 81%, P  = 0.04) and higher accuracy (93% vs. 82%, P  < 0.01), compared to those of CECT, while A-MRI showed comparable sensitivity (91% vs. 91%, P  = 0.42) and accuracy (97% vs. 98%, P  = 0.06) to that of standard liver MRI. On a per-lesion-based analysis, A-MRI exhibited significantly superior lesion detectability than that of CECT (figure of merit 0.91 vs. 0.77, P  < 0.01) and comparable to that of standard liver MRI (figure of merit 0.91 vs. 0.92, P =  0.75). A-MRI exhibited higher sensitivity and diagnostic accuracy than those of CECT in the post-treatment evaluation of RC, while it showed comparable performances with standard liver MRI. A-MRI provides diagnostic added value in the follow-up of RC patients.
ingestedContentSummary.title: Utility of abbreviated MRI in the post-treatment evaluation of rectal cancer - Sungeun Park, Hee Sun Park, Siwon Jang, Jungheum Cho, Jae Hyun Kim, Mi Hye Yu, Sung Il Jung, Young Jun Kim, Dae-Yong Hwang, 2024

ingestedContentSummary.title: Call for a new Editor-in-Chief: Acta Radiologica / Acta Radiologica Open, 2024

message.text:
Call for new chief editor – Acta Radiologica/Acta Radiologica Open.
Acta Radiologica is currently seeking a qualified individual to assume the role of Chief Editor. Our esteemed present chief editor, Professor Henrik Thomsen, will retire on December 31, 2024, having served in this position with distinction.
The Acta Radiologica's Board is actively engaged in the identification of Professor Thomsen's successor for a 5-year term, with the possibility of extension, commencing on January 1, 2025.
Applicant Qualifications: Prospective candidates should possess the following qualifications:
International reputation in medical imaging and scientific leadership
Experience in clinical radiology- and multidisciplinary research
Extensive experience in planning, writing, and presenting scientific manuscripts
Editorial experience, High proficiency in English (both verbal and written)
Well-organized with the ability to prioritize and meet deadlines, Recognized for diplomacy and networking skills.
 
Responsibilities and Tasks: The selected Chief Editor will be responsible for:
Overseeing all aspects of the journal's peer-review process to ensure efficiency and transparency, including the implementation of measures for fast turnaround times.
Introducing a pre-review mechanism and dedicated fast-track review processes, such as for late-breaking clinical trials in Radiology.
Developing and implementing a social media strategy to enhance community outreach.
Collaborating with the Editorial Office team, Acta Radiologica Board, and Sage to maintain and enhance editorial and publishing standards.
 
Application Requirements: Candidates are requested to submit the following documents with their formal application: 
Cover letter summarizing their vision, perspectives and goals for the journal.
Curriculum Vitae (detailed), including all publications and achievements.
Vision statement with perspectives and strategy for the further development of Acta Radiologica.
Strategy on building a supportive and inclusive culture based on the values of diversity, 
equity, and inclusion for the editorial board and the editors team
Nordic citizenship 
 
We encourage interested individuals with the requisite qualifications to submit their applications by June 14, 2024. Applications and inquiries should be directed to Lone.Friis.02@regionh.dk.
For additional information, please direct inquiries to the current Chief Editor, Prof. Henrik Thomsen, via email at eic.acta.radiol@gmail.com. 
An Evaluation Committee, comprising members of the board, has been constituted to oversee the selection process. The deadline for submitting applications is extended to June 14, 2024.  Candidates will receive more information about the process, after closing date.
Remuneration for the position will be determined through negotiation.
Individuals interested in applying are kindly requested to submit a comprehensive application to the Secretary, Lone Friis, at lone.friis.02@regionh.dk.
Happy to have started as Chairman of the board for #ActaRadiologica and #ActaRadiologicaOpen
